data.title: Top Women in Communications Awards 2022
data.text:
University of California, Irvine

Ria Marie Carlson forges partnerships to benefit a wide array of publics

At University of California, Irvine, Ria Marie Carlson rebranded the universitys identity, helped bring global companies to the UCI Research Park and crafted messaging that drew Barack Obama as a commencement speaker. She deserves her place in the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

When she arrived at the University of California, Irvine, Ria Marie Carlson had a vision and a goal: for UCI to be recognized as one of the worlds finest universities. Bringing more than 20 years of experience at publicly traded corporations, Carlson offered a fresh perspective to the world of higher education.

Carlson leads UCIs Office of Strategic Communications and Public Affairs, providing internal and external communications services for an institution the size of a small city, with some 30,000 students, 22,000 employees, 16 schools and a medical center with a 500,000-square-foot hospital and trauma center.

As chief communications officer, Carlson rebranded the university, differentiating it from others to broaden its reach and visibility. A national advertising campaign and a global media relations program garnered top-tier coverage of the project. The media relations effort spotlighted groundbreaking UCI research programs in local, national and international media markets, and continues to showcase the work of UCIs faculty, students and staff.

Carlson played a pivotal role in developing the messaging and outreach strategies that convinced former President Barack Obama to address the UCI class of 2014 graduates. During his 30-minute speech, Obama highlighted UCIs ambitions and innovations, including its commitment to tackling climate change with science-based, actionable solutions, and UCIs Nobel Prize-winning professor-student duo whose research led to better understanding of climate change. The speech earned national and international media attention.

Carlson also creates partnerships that benefit UCIs Orange County community. She worked with private real estate firm The Irvine Company to rebrand University Research Park, a 185-acre workplace community, as UCI Research Park; its now home to Intel, Cisco and more of some of the worlds most influential companies.

The partnership allows students and faculty to work and form relationships with both global corporations and pioneering startups. Carlson has also formed partnerships with California State University, Fullerton, Santa Ana Unified School district and Santa Ana Community College.

U.S. Sugar

Judy Clayton Sanchez helps neighbors feed neighbors with U.S. Sugar

Judy Clayton Sanchezs work with U.S. Sugar and within her community is making lasting change. Her dedication and efforts have earned her a well-deserved spot in Ragans Women in Communications Hall of Fame in our Top Women in Communications Awards.

Judy Clayton Sanchez grew up in and around farms in the South, a background that made her uniquely qualified for her position as senior director of corporate communications and public affairs for U.S. Sugar. With her ability to communicate the complex processes involved in farming to the general public, Clayton Sanchez manages all media for U.S. Sugar. In an industry dominated by men, she is not only a mentor to other women, but she also earns the respect of the men with whom she works, said Jeanmarie Ferrara, EVP of Wragg & Casas.

Having worked for U.S. Sugar since 1993, Clayton Sanchez has become an authority on her subject, and is respected for both her communications skills and dedication to the sugar industry.

At the beginning of the pandemic, Clayton Sanchez initiated the community campaign Neighbors Feeding Neighbors. Shes seen to it that U.S. Sugar has made donations within their community, including the purchase of new band uniforms for a local school. As former member of the South Florida Water Management Districts Water Resources Advisory Commission, she also works to ensure several cities in Florida have access to clean water, highlighting her commitment to local causes.

Palm Beach County Commissioner Melissa McKinlay says, Judy is a leader among her peers in the communications world, and our rural farming region has benefited significantly because of her strong voice. Her vast knowledge and skill in educating people about the importance of agriculture has served our community very well over the years. Congratulations to Judy Clayton Sanchez.

SD

Royal Caribbean Group

Rosanna Fiskes career spans the world of corporations, education and the nonprofit sector

Rosanna Fiske has led executive searches, helmed the PRSA and counseled college students in the PR field. That puts her in the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Rosanna Fiske currently serves as Royal Caribbean Groups global chief communications officer, making her responsible for, among other things, internal communications for more than 80,000 employees. But she has worn many hats throughout her PR career, overseeing product launches, managing crisis communications and handling strategic planning initiatives both domestically and internationally.

Fiske has served as CEO and chair of the Public Relations Society of America (PRSA)  the first Latina CEO in the organizations 70-plus-year history. As chair of PRSAs first National Diversity Committee, she created a first-of-its-kind Diversity Toolkit to guide national, district, chapter and section leaders in promoting greater inclusivity. The toolkit became an essential document for research studies and training manuals inside and outside the PR profession.

During her tenure as a professor at Florida International Universitys School of Communication and Journalism, Fiske led a team that refocused and rebranded the masters program in global strategic communications. She also developed a recruitment strategy to attract more qualified students, doubling the number of applicants within 18 months and increasing student enrollment by nearly 40%.

Fiskes commitment to mentoring and career counseling at FIU influenced many students lives. One student contacted her for advice on what track to take: creative development or account management? Fiske suggested PR classes and PRSA meetings, and also counseled her; the student completed two internships and got a job offer immediately after graduation.

Fiskes commitment to diversity is evident in the more than 100 conferences and seminars about diversity, inclusion and multiculturalism she has participated in.

She has also volunteered her time and expertise to helping nonprofits recruit candidates for executive leadership roles. For the Beacon Council, a public and private nonprofit agency supporting minority-owned businesses in Miami Dade, Fiske served as search committee chair as the council looked for a new CMO. She also contributed to the creation of an executive search process for a new executive director of the Washington D.C.-based arm of the National Education Association.

Westinghouse Electric Company

Marta Ronquillo Newhart spearheaded a challenging project to lead a clean energy revolution

For Westinghouse, Marta Ronquillo Newhart was tasked with making nuclear energy part of the solution to climate change. She used the talents and experience that have put her into the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As a newly appointed chief communications officer to a recently appointed CEO at a company emerging from Chapter 11, Marta Ronquillo Newhart found herself working in a highly regulated and misunderstood industry with a skeleton crew of a marketing communications team when she took the reins of the iconic Westinghouse brand in spring 2020.

Newharts assignment at Westinghouse Electric Company was to lead a clean energy revolution with a new purpose statement, visual brand identity and website that depicted the ability of nuclear energy to empower the world safely and sustainably. Making an already challenging assignment more difficult, the Westinghouse brand is owned by CBS, but Westinghouse Electric Company is owned by a private equity firm.

Despite these constraints, Newhart worked to amplify the voice of Westinghouse and the nuclear industry. As a result of her efforts, politicians, big thinkers like Bill Gates and young energy activists are starting to think of nuclear power as a reliable and resilient component of the clean energy equation.

Newhart began repositioning the brand under already challenging market and ownership circumstances just as the COVID-19 pandemic began. Despite the obstacles, Newhart worked to rebuild and reshape her team into a premiere international marketing communications function remotely. She and her new team quickly went to work, creating a new brand identity, narrative and storytelling strategy to bridge the gap between Westinghouse and its stakeholders.

Often the first or only Latina in a top position, Newhart, who has an MBA from Pepperdine University, focuses on uncovering and articulating complex issues to prompt understanding, acceptance and action. She has built her reputation on developing and nurturing diverse groups of strategic storytellers who employ marketing and communications to generate revenue.

Newhart believes communications is a great equalizer: If you are creative and understand the power of words, building brands and connecting with consumers you will be successfulespecially if someone takes the time to show you the way, she says.

Simmons University

Bec Rollins travels the world to help people and share their humanity

Pathfinder Internationals chief communications officer is also a talented photojournalist and visual storytellerand a member of the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

You might see Bec Rollins in a cholera treatment center in Mirebalais or a pediatric cancer ward in Butaro, perhaps not noticing her among her fellow mothers and friends there. Back at Pathfinder Internationals office in Boston, her stories wouldnt center on what she saw or did, but on what she captured with her camera. In the portrait of a mother and her child you would see an entire life story, often painful but still hopeful, and maybe understand a little more of your own story as well.

Pathfinder International is a global health organization devoted to supporting the rights of women to make their own reproductive health decisions. Rollins, Pathfinders chief communications officer, is a skilled photojournalist and visual storyteller who works tirelessly to ensure that organizations acknowledge, name, celebrate, and faithfully collaborate with the same people who are the subjects of Pathfinders marketing and fundraising communications.

Rollins has taken this approach for 30 years. During international crisis responses, like the Ebola outbreak in West Africa or the flooding disaster in Peru, her work has demonstrated that the most effective stories show how much people of all stripes depend on each other, and that no matter how big the crowd is, every face has a name worth knowing. Its a perspective thats rubbed off on CEOs and board members throughout her career,

Even now, though, as a seasoned executive, she devotes much of her time to mentoring the youngest and least experienced people around her. In depicting people with truth and kindness, Rollins always finds room for teaching and learning.

Intel

Melissa Beers excelled at speedy rollout of new comms channels at Intel

Melissa Beers, channels strategist at Intel, rolled out two brand-new communications channels in just six months. The bridges she built throughout Intel stretch from the technical tools the organization makes and uses to the people who put them through their real-world paces. To launch both channels, she needed organizational, technical and people skills to all come together. Her efforts led to recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Taking on additional work on top of her job title led Melissa Beers to success. As well as serving as a communication channels strategist, she launched two new communications platforms. Both platforms launched on time, replacing an end-of-life channel and saving the company time and money. The new platforms are mobile responsive, branded and available on desktop and mobile. After six weeks, more than 105,000 employees had registered on the new mobile platform.

Her work launching the new channels included bringing together stakeholders and employees from IT, the vendor, communicators on her team and across the company. First, she set up a steering committee to align company-wide communications governance and reduce confusion. She took stock of what embedded communicators needed and wanted from their tools. From there, she worked with two vendors and two IT groups on the rollout. She made sure all 100+ communicators who would work on the new platforms were up to speed and organized a global contest, swag, and welcome parties to make the change into an exciting, morale-boosting occasion.

Working as a liaison between people and the tech that can improve their work and life is a process of iteration. Beers bedrock for this process is gathering input from those using the tool, testing her understanding of the use cases to understand if a solution is viable for the user. Next, she does research to understand the end user experience. By using this process of rigorous knowledge, in-depth research, and talking to real people, she uses tech to meet employees where their needs are.

MC

HIMSS

Leia Lovely Bradford brings a keen sense for human connection to communications

Leia Lovely Bradford, MSc, program manager of strategic communications at HIMSS, brings her experience with recruitment to communications. From connecting to the media to attracting and retaining talent, its all about the human element. Her efforts have landed her among the Bridge Builders in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

At the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS), the theme of Leia Lovely Bradfords career has been supporting clear and valuable communication among individuals with different but connected goals. Her ability to build bridges has been shown in her recruitment work, where she prioritizes continuous and effective communication. She took the skills she learned in recruitment to the planning and execution of press activities for the HIMSS Global Conference & Exhibition press room. Other accomplishments this year include:

Coordinating press welcome activities, special events and onsite support for the conference

Strategically crafting content to actively engage internal and external audiences

Developing new and effective ways to connect press with upcoming products, services and events

Staying up to date with industry trends

Engaging with press with appropriate beats to provide a platform that elevate HIMSS in the media

For Lovely Bradford, building bridges is only the first step. The second, and more important step, is to get people to actually step onto them and walk across. This focus on moving people to action while building trust has brought her success in her seven years with HIMSS. She knows a large part of problem-solving is about forming meaningful bonds with people that make them want to solve the problem and help them understand how the solution will help.

MC

ARUP Laboratories

Lisa Carricaburu successfully managed change during pandemic

Lisa Carricaburu, director of marketing communications and clinical decision support at ARUP Laboratories, earns recognition as one of our Bridge Builders in Ragans Top Women in Communications for building bridges in a hard time. Stepping into a higher leadership position in the thick of the pandemic, she improved the organizations media mentions and exceeded event participation goals by more than nine times.

Nonprofit national reference laboratory ARUP Laboratories was a critical part of the COVID-19 response. As a testing facility, it saw an influx of COVID-19 testing. In response, Lisa Carricaburus communications team took things in hand. Carricaburu thrived under pressure, receiving a promotion to director of marketing communications and clinical decision support in October 2020. She pioneered a virtual Lab Leadership Symposium to improve ARUPs reputation, which brought in more than 950 people after setting a modest goal of 100 participants. Under her leadership, media mentions grew to more than 181 between March and October 2020. Her 29 news releases over the next year generated another 138 mentions.

During the pandemic in particular, she organized the creation of external COVID-19 testing information and resource pages for health-care clients and the public. These involved making, highly technical, scientific content that required extensive review and vetting by medical directors compelling and readable. Carricaburu steered this effort successfully, as the pages have drawn over 200,000 views. She also oversaw 15 COVID-19-related podcasts, 50+ company articles, and 11 educational webinars or videos.

If the pandemic wasnt enough of a change, Carricaburu was also faced with promoting positive messages around the retirement of the CEO and president and the opening of a new facility. Set for June 2021, both were changed from virtual to in-person under her supervision as pandemic restrictions lifted.

Internally, she faced the challenge of unfavorable employee perceptions of leadership. To counter this, she oversaw the creation of first a regular CEO email, a leadership feedback portal and COVID-19 intranet pages. Plus, she established a central review team for communications quality control in support of the organizations marketing writers. With pressure on the organization, she used all her expertise to support her employees and make the labs a trusted authority in the eyes of the public.

MC

Robert Bosch LLC

Alissa Cleland handles connections throughout a global, multi-billion-dollar organization

Alissa Cleland, vice president of corporate communications and government affairs, Americas and Australia at Robert Bosch LLC, works as a bridge builder as her voice reaches across the U.S. and international employees. From podcasts to presentations to leadership, she makes herself heard with a global reach. She has been recognized as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Alissa Clelands reach at technology company Bosch is global. As a leader in the companys communications and government affairs activities in North America, South America and Australia, she needs to build bridges between technology and the human element. navigating complex topics within the highest levels to drive the right communication strategy.

She took the lead on the creation of the companys first two podcasts for current and former employees. That includes From Know How to Wow, the organizations first international podcast.

During COVID-19, Cleland juggled an internal communication strategy centering around empathy, authenticity, transparency and external efforts focused on business continuity. She featured regular associate messages from the organization president, promotions around health and safety protocol, and a toolkit to support communication at more than 100 locations. Her external strategies closely engaged with trade organizations and local communities, preserving essential work at the companys manufacturing plants.

The company and her coworkers express their trust in her in a variety of ways, including seeking her expertise in her capacity as a member of the N.A. Executive Committee, Benefits Committee and Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Council. Shes also a member of the companys global executive council for communications and government affairs, where she leads international project teams. What else displays building bridges but encouraging global cooperation within a complex, multi-billion-dollar organization?

During the pandemic, she also spoke to the global executive leadership team on the topic Leading in the New Normal. Going forward, she is confidently driving the company through its post-pandemic cultural evolution.

MC

Xero

Karen Davis tripled the size of her communications team to build not just bridges, but avenues

As executive general manager of communications at Xero, Karen Davis helped transform the organization. From proving herself to a CTO unconvinced about the value of communications to punching with the strength of a much larger company, she has more than proved the worth of her work. Her efforts have landed her among the Bridge Builder honorees in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As a cloud-based accounting software company, Xero is all about making day-to-day work easier for small businesses. When Karen Davis first arrived at the organization in 2018, it needed some streamlining of its own. While the company was successful and expanding globally, it needed a bridge-builder when it came to communications in particular. The communications team was understaffed, underfunded and not globally aligned with a headquarters function. Davis brought her experience with former employers PwC and IBM into play quickly, transforming how the company looked at communications and showing what a difference a strong, aligned team made.

When Karen arrived at Xero, its safe to say I was personally unconvinced about the value of communications, said Mark Rees, Chief Technology Officer, Xero. In a remarkably brief period of time, Karen turned that around  showing me the difference a high-caliber communications team can deliver as my organization drives a sweeping change management program that touches every aspect of Xeros technology infrastructure. Im a believer, an advocate, and I consider Karen a most trusted advisor.

Despite the challenges of growing an organization during COVID-19 or the difficulty of hiring and retaining employees today, Davis made the case for the power of good communications professionals and got the leadership buy-in to triple the size of the communications team.

Some of her accomplishments addressed todays urgent climate transformation. She created a new social and environmental impact strategy and team, as well as launching Xeros environmental impact program. Her efforts drove the company to achieve a net zero energy certification from the Australian government.

Karen Davis took a small communication team and engineered a strategic function that can compete on equal footing with any platform company, including companies that are many times larger than Xero, said Rachael Powell, Chief Customer Officer at Xero. The transformation reflects her personal leadership on two levels: the coaching and mentoring of a team that punches well over its weight, and her ability to create trusted relationships across our C-Suite and Board.

MC

SWM International

Mary Gibson brings SWM Internationals varied facets together

For Mary Gibson, director of Enterprise & Brand Communications at SWM International, a lot was riding on the companys 25th anniversary. How to bring disparate parts of a widely distributed organization together? She brought the message into the spotlight  and all during the pandemic. These efforts led to recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Like many people, Mary Gibson had grand plans for 2020 that needed to rapidly change in the face of the pandemic. For SWM International, it was already a year of transformation. The companys 25th anniversary as a standalone public company was coming in November, and the goal was to focus employee messaging around unity. As SWM International includes a legacy company and multiple new acquisitions, showing the employees how the different areas of the company were alike was key for morale and a feeling of continuity and long-term success.

Even though they couldnt hold planned events in person, the COVID-19 versions of the celebration were very successful. A month-long employee campaign in June 2020 themed around the anniversary drove a 14% increase in traffic on the intranet. LinkedIn posts created for the occasion received more than 12,000 impressions.

When SWM International acquired UK public company Scapa Group Plc, it could have emphasized to employees that SWM is made up of splintered, loosely connected acquired companies. Instead, Gibson had the messaging in hand to bring Scapa smoothly into the fold. She ran a team of internal and external experts as they shaped a global celebratory launch for the new company. Its tagline: Greater Together. The team created a signature graphic for Teams backdrops, digital screens, posters and other materials, an email from the CEO with a video message, a SWM + Scapa sizzle video, and a video of employees sharing selfies from all around the new company.

Since then, the Greater Together theme has been expanded to a wide variety of employee communications. In 2022, the team hopes to continue to illustrate the companys shared purpose for external communications.

MC

Amazon

Leslie Letts headlines Amazons far-reaching global communications team

As global director of internal communications and community engagement at Amazons Worldwide Communications team, Leslie Letts helps keep the companys products and services moving. In addition to coming into a new role just as COVID-19 hit the United States in March 2020, she has also overseen several high-profile product releases in the course of her storied career. Her works has earned her recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As a leader in Amazons Worldwide Communications team, Leslie Letts is a bridge between corporate and the companys hundreds of thousands of front-line employees. As supply chains, economies and daily life have felt the impact and the aftershocks of COVID-19, she has had to stand strong in her efforts to continue delivering uninterrupted communications, sharing important corporate updates to employees across the globe and bringing critical storytelling and notifications to internal and external audiences. Her reach extends to Amazons frontline employees and managers across 15 countries.

She led from the front as Amazon Operations global director of internal communications & community engagement since March 2020, starting in the pivotal time at which Americans were realizing the pandemic was going to change the way work, daily life and the global economy functioned.

Throughout the pandemic, her priorities were to keep employees up-to date on COVID safety measures and protocols, making sure they were well-informed on whats happening at work every day, and most importantly, felt supported by the company. Identifying, creating, ramping up and deploying these communications to a massive global audience takes experience, skill, organization, determination and the ability to build bridges. Whether those bridges are between employees and departments in different countries or between the day pandemic restrictions are called and the day they are lifted, Amazon Worldwide Communications trusts Letts to get the job done.

MC

Bellmont Partners

Bridget Nelson Monroe supports community during tough times

Bellmont Partners put forward public relations professional Bridget Monroe for the Top Women in Communications award as a Bridge Builder. She rose to the occasion during COVID-19, bringing her experience in journalism and a commitment to nonprofits to her effective strategies.

Bridget Nelson Monroes bridges stretch from the very beginning of Bellmont Partners. As one of the first employees, she knows the 18-person business inside and out. During her tenure, Bellmont Partners was named a Best Workplace by Inc. Magazine for three years in a row. In more than three years, no employees have left the company. Monroe runs weekly all-team Zoom huddles, launched the agencys e-newsletter, co-led the creation of the Diversity, Inclusion & Antiracism Committee and led the creation of the COVID-19 office reopening plan. She was promoted to partner in May as a result of her many years of productive effort. Like many people in the industry, Monroes career also features a bridge between journalism and public relations.

She has also made a big impact on her community. As a leader of the agencys nonprofit practice group, her work benefits dozens of Minnesota-based nonprofit clients and the people under their care. She helped her clients, including two of the states largest nonprofits, pivot to pandemic precautions during COVID-19. Her everyday work also helped organizations on the front lines with messaging, crisis communications, remotely produced podcasts, digital advertising and Facebook Live town halls. Some of these were, by necessity, quick-turn, new-for-the-client solutions taking advantage of online connections in a time when in-person meetings were unsafe.

She also had a hand in the Bellmont Gives Back initiative, which provides employees with the time and resources necessary to support community organizations and causes important to them. In 2020, team members contributed 809 hours to 53 organizations during the work week. With Monroes wealth of experience, she is a cornerstone of Bellmont Partners.

MC

CNSI

Janice Moore gives back to her community in a time of change

Janice Moore, internal communications manager at health information technology company CNSI, came in on the ground floor as CNSI was creating a new mission and values. She made the difficult COVID-19 period a time of positive change, finding creative methods to promote the organizations values. Plus, her efforts to increase employee giving brought in $25,000 for a local food drive and earned her recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Janice Moore faced a challenge: joining CNSI. She needed to write internal communications for a team that had gone through many changes, with a new management team, vision and mission at the same time as people were starting to work from home. That meant that she needed to build bridges within the organization quickly to create coherence in a time of change. She helped the company create an intentional focus around its newly forged values.

In addition to creating a mission, a vision, a values relaunch campaign, using multimedia and elevating voices of employees at all levels of the company, she also developed creative ways to show off the new values. The company designed T-shirts with each of the values. From there, employees could pick their favorite and have the shirt shipped to them. Janice was also instrumental in designing digital backgrounds for video calls, reviving a stale intranet, and creating bi-weekly posts focused on the organizations mission.

This dedication and thoroughness extends to her day-to-day work as well. In 2020, she created a monthly newsletter and wrote a monthly CEO column to help the employees get to know leadership.

When it comes to giving back to the community, Moore revived an inactive corporate responsibility program. In December 2020 she organized a community-wide food drive, which brought in $25,000 in employee contributions. She brought a new coat of paint to the corporate social responsibility team and helped it go global, supporting nurses and schools in the U.S. and India and raising $5,000 in pre-packaged food items and masks to U.S. food pantries.

MC

The American Institutes for Research (AIR)

Makini Nyanteh brings her knowledge to the American Institutes for Research

As vice president of Communications & Public Affairs for the American Institutes for Research (AIR), Makini Nyanteh changed the organizations culture. She took the lead on a complete rebrand and is recognized as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

With the American Institutes for Researchs background in science, it took an extended hand to connect the worlds of academia and marketing. AIRs leadership and staff were nervous about bringing branding and marketing into their efforts, so Makini Nyantehs first job was to take practical steps toward a total cultural change. Her bridge needed to stretch from her background in Big Pharma, public utilities and private industry to AIRs research and evidence. A nonpartisan, not-for-profit institution, AIR seeks to advance education and equity through behavioral and social science research, as well as delivering technical assistance.

On the audience-facing side, Nyantehs job was to rebrand AIRs website and the entire look and feel of the organizations public face. After the new website launch, the site saw a nearly 25% increase in site traffic compared to the same time period last year.

The new branding statement, Advancing Evidence, Improving Lives, encapsulates the rebranding effort to portray the organization with authority and dignity, plus a modern look. Over the course of several months, Nyanteh was integral to coordinating between internal and external stakeholders and creating a concise new mission statement to sum up AIRs efforts as well: AIRs mission is to generate and use rigorous evidence that contributes to a better, more equitable world.

Communicating entirely new branding during the pandemic, while the offices were closed, presented its own challenges. At the same time, AIR was integrating two other research organizations recently acquired. Nyanteh needed to communicate about the new brand and website, ensuring staff, clients and partners understood how to use the brand language and visuals. She rose to the occasion.

AIRs Communications and Public Affairs team now thrives as a close-knit part of AIRs identity as a mission-driven organization. They played a key role in AIRs new $100 million Equity Initiative launched this year, having gained the organizations trust enough to plan and execute communications to address what AIR sees as our nations most pressing challenge: inequity.

What Makini has accomplished is about more than a new brand and new website, said AIR President and CEO David Myers. Its been about bringing people together, creating a culture of excellence, and moving our institutions communications efforts into the 21st century.

MC

Hy-Vee, Inc.

Ivy Sprague forges strong links in employee-owned grocery chain

For Ivy Sprague, communications manager at Hy-Vee, Inc., bridges the space between employee-owners and customers. Her work has garnered praise from her department as well as recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards. Although just one part of what is expected to be many more initiatives, the DEI programs she supported have also already broken new ground.

At Hy-Vee, Ivy Sprague brings her expertise to both internal and external communications. One aspect of her bridge-building comes from Hy-Vees status as an employee-owned company. An important part of her work is drafting quarterly letters for the 1,200 employee owners, which involves translating business information into easily digestible and useful content.

In her four years at Hy-Vee, Ivy has demonstrated that she is an invaluable member of our team through her expert counsel, pitch-perfect writing and impeccable work ethic, said Tina Potthoff, Hy-Vees senior vice president of communications. Most of all, I appreciate Ivys ability to connect people and ideas through her thoughtful approach and positive outlook. Ivy builds bridges for Hy-Vee every day.

Sprague is also the lead communicator for Hy-Vees One Step initiative, which sends a portion of proceeds from the sales of selected projects to programs supporting healthier living. She also helped in the effort that led to the West Des Moines Chamber of Commerce presenting Hy-Vee with a Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion (DEI) Workplace Excellence Award, as well as another regional diversity award yet to be announced.

Her bridge-building tools include email, social media, intranet stories and Retail Zipline, an employee communications platform available to all 86,000 Hy-Vee employees. In particular, she crosses department boundaries to work closely with human resources in a time in which finding (and keeping) the right employees can be a challenge. Last but not least, she uses her excellent communication skills to represent Hy-Vee on panels before community and industry groups.

MC

Kyowa Kirin, Inc.

Susan Thieles patient advocacy sets her work apart

Susan Thiele, director of patient advocacy and communications at Kyowa Kirin, Inc., is named a Bridge Builder and one of Ragans Top Women in Communications for her clear-eyed work. She quickly came up to speed in a new position and built bridges between patients who might otherwise have felt isolated by their diagnosis with a rare disease.

As a leader for PR, media relations and patient advocacy for two commercial brands, Susan Thiele has a lot of irons in the fire. She brings together marketing, sales, medical affairs, legal and regulatory teams for Kyowa Kirins efforts in specialty pharmaceuticals. She provides clarity and authority to both health-care providers and patients about both products.

One of those products, Poteligeo, is an infused therapy indicated for the treatment of rare forms of blood cancer. Because Thieles research found that patients diagnosed with rare diseases often lack a sense of community support, she created an ambassador program to bring patients together.

Susan is an exceptional bridge builder, said Sue Smith, vice president, oncology franchise. She has been an integrated and positive partner. Poteligeo Partners is a meaningful and innovative program that helps people understand and connect to a rare condition in a meaningful way. Susan led and orchestrated this work seamlessly. Her professionalism and dedication, along with expertise to help actual Poteligeo patients compliantly tell their stories, is the epitome of Kyowa Kirins commitment to patients.

I am impressed with everything Susan does, said Kristi Ambs and Tim Fraley, oncology thought leader liaisons She jumped right in from day one and quickly was well-versed in CTCL. Susan has such a passion for patients and it shows in all of her work. She is always willing to help, even if it is not in her job description. The patient ambassador program is top-notch and one of the most valuable programs for patients this company offers. We are truly blessed to have her here!

MC

Providence

Melissa Tizon kept the focus on health and truth during COVID-19

As the health system that treated the first known COVID-19 patient in the United States, Providence had no choice but to be a leading voice in the pandemic. Vice President of National Communication Melissa Tizon rose to the occasion, focusing the message on Providences trustworthiness and authority and earning recognition as a Bridge Builder in Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

Good communication is about responding to people as much as it is about pulling the right numbers, and success depends on both. At Providence health systems, Melissa Tizons communications leadership helped the organizations earned media reach an audience of 94 billion and increased share of voice from 33% to 44%, resulting in top SOV among peers.

Treating the first known COVID-19 patient in the country meant that Providence inevitably had the nations attention. Tizon was at the forefront of the effort to provide timely, trustworthy information in a time of mounting anxiety. If youre expecting the unexpected, youll want Amy Ponticello on your side, said a colleague. Throughout Ponticellos six-year stint with Lincoln Financial Group, she climbed the ranks from assistant vice president to vice president of corporate communications.

Prior to her promotion, Ponticello led the COVID-19 response and return-to-work planning. She also supported executive communications for human resources leaders, the CEO and the president.

Ponticello also took the lead in the diversity, equity and inclusion space. Her success is evident: Lincoln has earned 100% scores on the Corporate Equality Index and the Disability Equality Index and ranks among Forbes Best Large Employers and Best Employers for Women.

Her success was amplified when Ponticello moved into her current role. From that post, she oversees all human resources, information technology/digital, legal and enterprise strategic initiatives, including return-to-work communications.

As a well-respected communicator, stakeholders were quick to trust her expertise, which was greatly appreciated during the Great Resignation and as the pandemic continued and variants and vaccines emerged. Ponticello stepped up to manage employee concerns and handle media attention.

Ponticellos expanded role enabled her to lead the development of a framework for managing crisis communications across the enterprise. Her role representing leadership enables Ponticello to have a meaningful impact throughout the industry and to serve as an example for other companies when responding to crises.

As the academic year kicked off, the University of Notre Dame had a goal to prompt 13,000 students to return to its South Bend, Indiana campus during a pandemic.

After witnessing her topnotch work in handling the funeral of Father Theodore Hesburgh, who served as president of the university, and campus visits by then-vice presidents Joe Biden and Mike Pence, she was tapped for the COVID communications team in spring 2021. She oversaw messaging about testing, isolation and quarantine policies and procedures, and beyond.

Since then, Ryan has successfully managed communications emerging from the Coronavirus Response Unit (CRU), which collaborates with other campus departments to share information. Hot topics include symptomatic and asymptomatic testing, saliva vs. nasal swab testing, surveillance testing, isolation and quarantine policies and accommodations, contact tracing, vaccination opportunities, and mandates. Beyond the pandemic, Ryan provides counsel on other controversies related to Notre Dame.

Horizon House

Laura Tufts used creativity and a team approach to keep Horizon Houses residents connected

With limited resources, Laura Tufts managed to keep the residents of a retirement community connected and well-informed during the darkest days of the pandemic. For her ability to foster trust through honest communication and partnerships, Tufts has earned recognition in the Crisis Navigator category of Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As the pandemic swept from one side of the globe to the other, life became more challenging for everyone. Many of the things we take for granted such as socializing and sharing meals with one another immediately came to a halt.

During this time, Laura Tufts brought a sense of optimism and hope to Horizon House, a vibrant retirement community in Seattle. As the newly appointed head of marketing, sales and communications, Tufts helped establish a COVID Task Force, along with assistance from the residents Health Advisory Group.

She supported the management and distribution of communication materials to Horizon Houses 550 residents. Unfortunately, the isolation that was necessary for keeping everyone safe also made a huge impact on residents well-being.

Since Horizon Houses communications systems werent up-to-date, Tufts used teamwork and a dash of creativity to keep everyone connected. With support from the technology team, she helped residents embrace new tools and technology. During a stagnant era, people at Horizon House learned to master new skills.

With help from her colleagues in technology, Tufts helped establish the K4 Connect communication system. Residents stayed connected via digital screens, an internal TV channel, and an Amazon Alexa Echo Dot, which was donated by Amazon.

Since Tufts understood the importance of sharing Horizon Houses news with families and friends in real time, she encouraged residents to use the COVID-19 Updates webpage and social media. The page quickly became a trusted, transparent source of information.

Tufts also collaborated with the information technology team to unveil an app that allows residents to learn about community offerings. They can use the app to sign up for events, view the daily menu, access a resident directory and schedule hair, gym, and massage appointments. The social-centric app also allows residents to converse and share information with friends and family.

Adrienne Webb was well-prepared for her mission as commander of pandemic-related communications at Providence Medical Group, due to strong foundational systems. For her success, Webb was named an honoree in the Crisis Navigator category of Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

When the first U.S. COVID-19 patient landed at Providence hospital in Everett, Washington, Adrienne Webb knew she was in the eye of a career-defining storm. As the director of communications assigned to national issues management, Webb served as COVID-19 public information officer.

Webb ensures that the information Providence shares is factual, understandable and current. During the pandemic, this became particularly challenging since information about testing, personal protective equipment and the virulence of the virus changed almost hourly. To complicate matters, so much of the news was presented with a political spin. Regardless of these challenges, Webb was well prepared for her mission.

Early on, she developed Providences issues and reputation management guidebook. To facilitate the sharing of information, Webb aligned all communication teams across seven states. She also developed protocols and procedures to help her colleagues on the national and regional communication teams. Webb and her team relied on these foundational tools and systems, which proved to be stormproof during the healthcare crisis.

A virtual emergency operations center was already in place to support the preparation and response to the COVID-19 crisis across the organization. Local and regional communication leaders plugged into their command centers so they could exchange information and drive local strategy. Channels that were already established for routine input and feedback enabled decision makers to continually evaluate approaches and make revisions to achieve their goals.

Webbs ability to collaborate with all levels and departments helped pave the way to success. Regional leaders and C-suite executives depended on her expert advice and her communications colleagues relied on live updates, so they could, in turn, provide accurate information and prepare local spokespeople with the latest information. Webbs work was also pivotal for Providences extraordinary media effort, which included regular CNN updates and local and regional press reports.

MikeWorldWide

Carreen Winters finds silver linings and transforms negative events into positive brand stories

Carreen Winters demonstrated her keen ability to overcome obstacles as she polished the reputations of two clients in crisis mode. Thanks to her work, both clients have been recognized for reaching new milestones. For her efforts, Winters received recognition in the Crisis Navigator category of Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As chief strategy officer at public relations agency MikeWorldWide, Carreen Winters ensures that C-suite leaders use their platforms to support their companys missions and values.

Beyond advancing MikeWorldWides DEI capability, Winters offers guidance to clients as they strive to better represent a range of voices and perspectives. Working across diverse fields, she keeps abreast of current events and the changes that have been taking place in todays corporate arena. In fact, thats where this star shines brightest.

Winters has a talent for providing a path forward during uncertain, chaotic times. The Washington Football Team certainly wasnt regarded as a winner before Winters stepped in to tackle its identity issues.

Since 1991, the team continually failed to win a Super Bowl. It also had a long history of failing to win a playoff game. Despite a frenzy of controversy around allegations that the team was hostile to women, Winters put a positive spin on its scandal-rocked image.

She cast the spotlight on the achievements of Jason Wright, the first Black team president in NFL history. Reaching this pinnacle required a clear line of demarcation between the old team and the new. Winters proved her success when the teams negative sentiment dropped from 97% to 10%.

She also demonstrated her steely resolve and ability to influence when she managed a volatile situation for Smithfield Foods  a pork producer with more than 40,000 employees and 40 facilities nationwide.

When its Sioux Falls, SD facility was identified as an early hot spot for COVID-19, Winters helped the company prove its commitment to safety. She helped silence the voices from a group of bold, often misinformed critics, which ranged from politicians to unions, community leaders and the public. After months of hard work, The Wall Street Journal spotlighted an editorial heralding Smithfield as a company that did everything possible to keep workers safe.

Sara Aghajanian, MPH has always strived to level the playing field for people who hail from various backgrounds. For her success in getting 98% of employees to believe that the communications agency is committed to DE&I, Aghajanian was recognized in the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Champion category of Ragans Top Women in Communications Awards.

As a child of Iranian immigrants, DE&I is part of Aghajanians DNA. In her first job, she was involved in resettling refugees from Afghanistan, Burundi, Iraq, and Nepal. To ensure that underserved communities are included, she went on to earn her Master of Public Health degree.

Ive always been passionate about making sure people of different backgrounds are heard, understood, respected, and have a seat at the table, says Aghajanian who serves as vice president of the agency that works to advance health and well-being.

Aghajanian knows firsthand that only when people feel safe, supported and respected can they bring their best selves to work and evolve into strong leaders. Thats why she helped shape Evoke KYNEs DE&I efforts.

In the wake of events in Charlottesville, Virginia, Aghajanian teamed up with leadership to demonstrate that they could lead by example. She lent her talents to developing the DE&I strategic framework and the first DE&I workgroup that would work to build and nurture a culture of inclusion.

Aghajanian has worked with Evoke KYNEs more than 40-person global workgroup and the head of DE&I to create live panel discussions around Black History Month and gender identity topics. Together, they advocated for leadership trainings and drove communications. She also spearheads the DE&I newsletter.

On the COVID front, Aghajanian led Evoke KYNEs efforts for Pandemic Action Network (PAN)a coalition that addresses preparedness and works toward global vaccine equity. In March, she helped coordinate a campaign with 40 African-American celebrities and influencers. She also developed an #ItsOurShot toolkit, empowering more than 150 partners to drive evidence-based vaccine conversations.

Under her leadership for PANs #WorldMaskWeek, culturally appropriate toolkits were created in Arabic, English, French, Japanese, Portuguese and Spanish. More than 170+ countries joined the efforts. The campaign is applauded for reaching more than 158 million social and 165 million media impressions.
